perturbation.original_text: 5.5 Additional Termination Rights. Google may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice to Distributor if: (a) Distributor breaches Clause 2 (License Grants and Restrictions), Clause 3.6 (EULA), Clause 3.7 (Accurate Reproduction), or Clause 6 (Confidential Information), (b) if Google believes, in good faith, that the Distributor has violated or caused Google to violate any Anti-Bribery Laws (as defined in Clause 8.5) or that such a violation is reasonably likely to occur, or (c) Distributor is in material breach of this Agreement more than [ * ] notwithstanding any cure of such breaches.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.5 Additional Termination Rights. Google may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice to Distributor if: (b) if Google believes, in good faith, that the Distributor has violated or caused Google to violate any Anti-Bribery Laws (as defined in Clause 8.5) or that such a violation is reasonably likely to occur, or (c) Distributor is in material breach of this Agreement more than [ * ] notwithstanding any cure of such breaches.
perturbation.explanation: Moving the EULA breach termination clause to a less prominent/obvious position makes it less clear when Google can terminate the agreement due to EULA violations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: 15 U.S. Code § 45 - Unfair methods of competition unlawful; prevention by Commission
perturbation.law_explanation: By obscuring the clear conditions under which Google can terminate the agreement for EULA breaches, this modification can create an unfair advantage for Google and leave distributors less informed about their rights, potentially violating Section 5 of the FTC Act regarding unfair practices.

perturbation.original_text: 11.5 Compliance with Export Laws. Distributor shall comply with all applicable export and re-export control laws and regulations ("Export Laws"), which the parties agree include: (a) the Export Administration Regulations maintained by the U.S. Department of Commerce, (b) trade and economic sanctions maintained by the U.S. Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control, and (c) the International Traffic in Arms Regulations maintained by the U.S. Department of State. Unless Distributor obtains prior authorisation required by applicable Export Laws, Distributor shall not export any Product to Cuba, Iran, North Korea, Sudan or Syria.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.5 Compliance with Export Laws. Unless Distributor obtains prior authorisation required by applicable Export Laws, Distributor shall not export any Product to Cuba, Iran, North Korea, Sudan or Syria.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the explicit statement that the distributor must comply with all applicable export and re-export control laws weakens the clause. Moving the statement of compliance, by omission, will place the onus on external regulation to ensure compliance, and reduces accountability within the contract itself.
perturbation.contradicted_law: 15 CFR § 732.3 - Steps for determining license requirements
perturbation.law_explanation: The deletion of the requirement to comply with the U.S. Export Administration Regulations (EAR) directly contradicts 15 CFR § 732.3, which outlines the steps for determining license requirements under the EAR. By removing the explicit compliance statement, the contract does not ensure that the distributor takes the necessary steps to determine and adhere to U.S. export licensing requirements, creating a potential violation of export control laws.

perturbation.original_text: 3.6 EULA. In connection with Distributor's distribution of the Products under this Agreement, and before the Google Toolbar or Chrome Browser can be installed by an End User, Distributor shall provide each End User with: (a) a clear statement inviting the End User to agree to the terms of the applicable EULA; (b) the opportunity for each End User to review such EULA via a hyperlink to such EULA: and (c) a button on which each End User may click indicating agreement to the terms of such EULA. In the event that an End User does not affirmatively agree to install the Google Toolbar or Chrome Browser, by clicking on the button to agree to the terms of the applicable EULA, then the Google Toolbar or Chrome Browser (as applicable) shall not be installed on such End User's computer.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.6 EULA. In connection with Distributor's distribution of the Products under this Agreement, and before the Google Toolbar or Chrome Browser can be installed by an End User, Distributor shall provide each End User with: (b) the opportunity for each End User to review such EULA via a hyperlink to such EULA: and (c) a button on which each End User may click indicating agreement to the terms of such EULA. In the event that an End User does not affirmatively agree to install the Google Toolbar or Chrome Browser, by clicking on the button to agree to the terms of the applicable EULA, then the Google Toolbar or Chrome Browser (as applicable) shall not be installed on such End User's computer.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the clause requiring a clear statement inviting the end-user to agree to the EULA, makes it more difficult for an end user to understand the terms and conditions of the download.
perturbation.law_explanation: By removing the 'clear statement inviting the End User to agree to the terms of the applicable EULA,' the modified clause potentially violates the CCPA, particularly Cal. Civ. Code § 1798.135, which emphasizes transparency and informed consent from consumers regarding data collection and usage. The absence of a clear and upfront invitation to review and agree to the EULA undermines the consumer's ability to make an informed decision about installing software, contradicting the CCPA's core principles of transparency and consumer control over their personal information.
